externalRef.thesu:comment: fullest philological and chemical discussion of what "filtering off" means in this phase, with comments on previous scholarship (Caley and Richards, Eichholz)

scholarContra.thesu:comment: "filtering off" interpreted differently: as referred to "decantation", involving water

"filtering off" interpreted differently: though translating ἀπηθοῦσιν with the ambiguous "is strained away", he specifies in the note ad loc. that water is involved ("In the manufacture of white lead, water would be poured on the scrapings and strained away")

"filtering off" interpreted differently: as "levigation" (in the chemical meaning of "wet separation by settling: coarser or denser particles fall to the bottom faster, while finer or lighter ones remain suspended longer"), involving water

"filtering off" interpreted differently: as "decantation" (as part of a levigation procedure, though they do not use the term "levigation"), involving water; they do not discuss this interpretation, deriving it from previous translations

supportForm.thesu:comment: It seems to explain why it makes sense that washed lead, as prepared by the second recipe, is "directly shaped" (into lozenges) at the end of the process. Lead white too is shaped into lozenges quite easily (see #tlg0656_tlg001.T185635), and since this kind of washed lead becomes similar to it (in properties), then it is both possible and convenient to shape it into lozenges "directly" after these few processing steps

textRef.snippet: ψιμύθιον […] τὸ ἐχόμενον καὶ […] τὰ λοιπά

ψιμύθιον δὲ γίνεται οὕτως · εἰς πιθάκνην πλατύστομον ἢ κεραμεᾶν γάστραν ἐγχέας δριμύτατον ὄξος ἀπέρεισαι μολυβδίνην πλίνθον ἐπὶ τὸ στόμα τοῦ κεραμίου , προυποκειμένου καλαμίνου ῥίπου , ἄνωθέν τε αὐτῆς ἐπίρριψον σκεπάσματα πρὸς τὸ μὴ διαπνεῖσθαι τὸ ὀξος · ὡς δʼ ἂν καταρρυεῖσα διαπέσῃ , τὸ μὲν ἐπαιωρούμενον καὶ καθαρὸν ὑγρὸν ἀπηθητέον , τὸ δὲ γλοιῶδες εἰς ἀγγεῖον ἐγχυτέον καὶ ξηραντέον ἐν ἡλίῳ . εἶτα ἀλεστέον ἐν χειρομυλίῳ ἢ λεαντέον ἄλλως καὶ σηστέον , 2 καὶ μετὰ ταῦτα τὸ λοιπὸν τοῦ στερεμνίου λεπτοποιητέον καὶ σηστέον , ἐναλλάξ τε τὰ αὐτὰ καὶ τρίτον καὶ τέταρτον ποιητέον

THESIS.paraphrasis: In order for (white and effective) lead white to come about in the best variety - to be used for ophthalmological properties - as well as in worse varieties, .(In summer, ) pour most pungent vinegar into a broad-mouthed jar OR pot-bellied clay jar, .Place a leaden brick on a lattice of reeds, .Lay the lattice of reeds with the leaden brick onto the mouth of the pot, .Above, throw over covers to prevent vinegar from evaporating, .Wait until (the leaden brick), crumbling down, has strained through (the lattice), .Decant away the clean fluid that floats on top (of the vinegar after the leaden brick has crumbled down in it), .Pour the (remaining) viscous fluid into a vessel, .Let the viscous fluid dry under the sun, .Smooth the dried substance with a hand-mill OR in any way, .Sift the ground substance, .The substance that is sifted away is the better variety of (white and effective) lead white, that should be picked also for ophthalmological properties, .Thin (with a hand-mill OR in any way) and sift what remains (above the sieve) of the solid substance {, repeat, and do it again a third and fourth time}, .The substances that are sifted away at each repeated thinning and sifting are progressively worse varieties of (white and effective) lead white

textRef.snippet: ψιμύθιον […] ἄμεινον […] τὸ πρῶτον ἀποσησθέν , ὃ καὶ εἰς τὰς ὀφθαλμικὰς παραλημπτέον δυνάμεις

THESIS.paraphrasis: The better variety, first to be sifted away, of (white and effective) lead white should be picked also for ophthalmological properties

scholarPro.thesu:comment: asseverative καὶ μὴν interpreted as introducing an argument not unrelated to Plutarch's point about the lead and pebbles having a 'drawing' effect on turbid particles: implicitly, it might be because they are cold or produce cold that they condense these particles around them (direct correlation of the properties and effects of denseness/condensation, coldness/cooling). This speculative interpretation is supposed the best available to explain why it would be reasonable to claim (almost as non-trivial) that lead and pebbles can mechanically 'draw' impurities towards them.

THESIS.paraphrasis: We performed in miniature the process described by Theophrastus to produce lead white: .We supported blocks of lead just above a 5% acetic acid solution in an open vessel, .White crusts formed on the blocks {due to corrosion}, .{Repeatedly}, {at intervals of about 10 days}, we scraped off these crusts, .We identified the obtained product as a lead acetate containing only a small proportion of lead carbonate, .We dissolved this in tap water, .{Almost immediately} we observed a turbidity {due to the formation of basic lead carbonate}, .We let the solution stand for a few hours, .A considerable amount of lead carbonate precipitated {due to the solution having absorbed enough carbon dioxide from the air}, ( .We obtained lead white in the same way as in Theophrastus's process )

SUPPORT.paraphrasis: "{Our miniature replication of Theophrastus' process}" JUSTIFIES) "In the small-scale processes used by the ancients to produce basic lead carbonate, air and the water used in the washing operations provided enough carbon dioxide to obtain this product"
{text} JUSTIFIES) "The ancient process described by Theophrastus resulted in the formation of lead white in just the same way as in {Our miniature replication of Theophrastus' process}"

supportForm.thesu:comment: providing two particular cases for Theophrastus's recipe being in need of such a complementation: 1. it is "incomplete"; 2. Dioscorides's recipe makes it "complete"; the need for the complementation is not justified deductively, but by pointing out one alleged disadvantage and one alleged advantage

microThemedFreeText.freeText: Ccommercial metallic lead cut in the shape of a brick

textRef.snippet: Sample PSI - 1 is the reproduced in laboratory white pow - der following Theophrastus ancient recipe On Stones . ( ref . On Stones § 56 above ) . Ccommercial metallic lead cut in the shape of a brick approx . 10 cm length by 5 cm width and 2 cm thickness , hanged over within a ceramic vessel where on its bottom vinegar was placed . The vessel was covered by a thin skin about 1 mm which is quasi - transparent to air ( i . e . it breaths ) ( see , fig . 8 ) . Following this shield it was placed under the sun ( on average 30 oC with a range 27 - 55 degrees ) for 10 days . Then the skin cover was removed and the lead brick taken out . A white powdered layer on its surface was removed by scratch , then washed in a marble mortar and ground down with marble pestle to a fine powder , following a dry out under the sun . Subsequently it was applied on a prepared wooden surface with a gypsum or calcite support

THESIS.paraphrasis: We reproduced in laboratory the white powder sample PSI-1 (which is composed of cerussite and hydrocerussite, and is therefore lead white) following Theophrastus's recipe (on the preparation of lead white): .We cut commercial metallic lead in the shape of a brick {approx. 10 cm length by 5 cm width by 2 cm thickness}, .We placed vinegar on the bottom of a ceramic vessel, .We hung the brick-shaped piece of lead over the vinegar within the ceramic vessel, .We covered the vessel with a skin {approx. 1 mm (in thickness)} quasi-transparent to air (i.e., such that it breathes), .We placed the vessel under the sun, .We waited {for 10 days}, {at temperatures of average 30 °C and a range of 27-55 degrees}, .We removed the skin cover, .We took the brick-shaped lead out, .We removed the white powdered layer (thus formed) on the surface of the lead by scratching, .In a marble mortar, we washed and ground down to a fine powder the white powdered layer using a marble pestle, .We waited for it to dry out under the sun, ( .We obtained the white powder sample PSI-1 (which is composed of cerussite and hydrocerussite, and is therefore lead white) following Theophrastus's recipe (on the preparation of lead white) ), .We applied it on a prepared wooden surface with a gypsum OR calcite support

SUPPORT.paraphrasis: {text} EXPLAINS) "[…] .We covered the vessel with a skin {approx. 1 mm (in thickness)} quasi-transparent to air […]"
